articles.headline: New Tools for Keeping the Lights On
articles.snippet: A decade after a record blackout crippled the Northeast, engineers are installing new devices that could stop future breakdowns.
articles.abstract: A decade after a record blackout crippled the Northeast, engineers are installing new devices that could stop future breakdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENSSELAER, N.Y. — After the lights went out for 50 million people from the Northeast to the Midwest on Aug. 14, 2003, investigators found readings from two obscure instruments that would have given them an hour’s warning — plenty of time to solve the problem if the devices had been wired to provide a stream of critical data.

articles.headline: Despite West’s Efforts, Afghan Youths Cling to Traditional Ways
articles.snippet: While young Afghans have cultivated Western trappings like cellphones and jeans, they have resisted the West’s efforts to instill values like expanded rights for women.
articles.abstract: While young Afghans have cultivated Western trappings like cellphones and jeans, they have resisted the West’s efforts to instill values like expanded rights for women.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Walk through the streets of Kabul and evidence of the West’s decade-long war literally clings to the Afghan youth: the American labels emblazoned on their shirts and jeans, the stylish sunglasses they wear, the cellphones they clutch to update their lives on Twitter and Facebook.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Habib Zahori

articles.headline: Banks Find S.&P. More Favorable in Bond Ratings
articles.snippet: S.& P. has been giving higher ratings than its big rivals to certain mortgage-backed securities just as Wall Street is eagerly trying to revive the market for these investments, according to an analysis conducted for The Times.
articles.abstract: S.& P. has been giving higher ratings than its big rivals to certain mortgage-backed securities just as Wall Street is eagerly trying to revive the market for these investments, according to an analysis conducted for The Times.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wall Street ratings game is back.

articles.headline: A Day’s Strike Seeks to Raise Fast-Food Pay
articles.snippet: From New York to several Midwestern cities, thousands of fast-food workers have been holding one-day strikes during peak mealtimes, drawing attention to their demands for much higher wages.
articles.abstract: From New York to several Midwestern cities, thousands of fast-food workers have been holding one-day strikes during peak mealtimes, drawing attention to their demands for much higher wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: From New York to several Midwestern cities, thousands of fast-food workers have been holding one-day strikes during peak mealtimes, quickly drawing national attention to their demands for much higher wages.

articles.headline: Defiant Russia Grants Snowden Year’s Asylum
articles.snippet: The refugee status in Russia was the first formal support from another government for Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor wanted for leaking details of surveillance programs.
articles.abstract: The refugee status in Russia was the first formal support from another government for Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor wanted for leaking details of surveillance programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Brushing aside pleas and warnings from President Obama and other senior Americans, Russia granted Edward J. Snowden temporary asylum and allowed him to walk free out of a Moscow airport transit zone on Thursday despite the risk of a breach in relations with the United States.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Andrew E. Kramer
